title: Young Adulthood: Aspirations and realities for living and learning in the 21st Century
abstractText:
This research aims to assess how young adults’ transitions to independent living and housing pathways have responded to recent social change:

  • including the expansion of higher education
  • economic recession
  • the increased unaffordability of housing.

We examine how young adult’s parental backgrounds and profiles of education and employment relate to their ambitions and success in achieving residential independence in the UK and how these relationships are modified by gender and ethnicity.

We will deliver policy and practitioner relevant research through the exploitation of the United Kingdom Household Longitudinal Survey (UKHLS), the English Housing Survey (EHS) and statistics on first year students’ term time residence from the Higher Education Statistics Authority (HESA).This approach provides a timely opportunity to re-conceptualise young people’s housing pathways after a period of considerable political, economic and social change.

Understanding trends in young adults’ living arrangements is required for marital status and household projections. Furthermore, welfare policies differentially affect housing careers by gender and parenthood status and this project will explore the potential impact of recent welfare reforms such as the extension in the age range affected by the limit to housing benefit resulting from the shared accommodation rate for men and women.
impactText: Impact from the project is on-going but our findings are informing the assumptions being used in National Population Projections made by the Office for National Statistics, and in the Department for Communities and Local Government 's Household Projections. We have also discussed the relevance of our findings with those responsible for making plans and policies for housing at a sub-national level including representatives from the Greater London Authority. findingsText:
We have quantified levels of economic uncertainty on young adults and specifically how these differ by gender, class and ethnicity. We have examined how economic uncertainty relates to the housing transitions of young adults, in particular their ability to leave the parental home. We have also identified young adults' aspirations for their learning - for example aspirations of teenagers to go on to college/education and how these differ by gender, class and race.
We have also examined how second generation minority youth differ from the white majority in their anticipated timing and form of their future family formation. Impact is on-going, but already our findings are feeding into ONS and DCLG population and household projections. We have also presented our work to think tanks e.g. Resolution Foundation, and to academic and policy audiences.
